newsitem.title: USA: Apparel boosts retailers' November sales.
newsitem.headline: Apparel boosts retailers' November sales.

text.p: Strong clothing sales with fewer promotions gave holiday cheer to some of the nation's largest store chains in November, retailers said Thursday, but consumer electronics lagged.
Calendar quirks made some year-to-year comparisons look negative because Thanksgiving was later this year, but analysts said that on a week-by-week basis, sales were strong.

"Everybody had been downplaying their expectations for November because of this calendar shift, and I actually think the numbers look pretty good," said Karen Sack, a retail analyst for Standard & Poor's.

Salomon Brothers said an improving retail environment for apparel, coupled with easier comparisons, led to gains in November sales. Its same-store sales index for the month rose 3.9 percent, compared with 2.9 percent a year ago.

"Concurrently, we believe that lower levels of discounting and strong inventory and expense controls have positioned the major retailers well in terms of profitability," Salomon analysts said in a report.

With holiday shopping off to a brisk start and inventories relatively lean, many retailers were able to put off launching profit-cutting sales and promotions, analysts said. Retailers typically earn a quarter or more of their year's profit during the holiday season.
"Inventories are in good shape ... we're looking for reduced clearance markdown activity in January, so that bodes well for profits," said Piper Jaffrey analyst Saul Yaari.
Even though many retailers offered fewer promotions, shoppers were still looking for bargains.
"Warehouse membership clubs were probably the stars overall for the month," Yaari said. "In terms of gift assortments, they improved, and they also have a lot more apparel than they used to."
Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retailer, said its November same-store sales rose 4 percent, including a 9 percent rise in sales at its Sam's Club warehouse stores.
Kmart Corp.'s U.S. same stores climbed 4.4 percent.

Sears, Roebuck and Co., meanwhile, said it rang up record sales over the Thanksgiving weekend. Although sales at stores open at least a year fell 0.7 percent for the four weeks ended Nov. 30, Sears said the month went according to plan.
"Record sales over Thanksgiving weekend produced an encouraging jump-start for a strong holiday shopping season at Sears," Sears Chairman Arthur Martinez said in a statement.
The Thanksgiving holiday fell on Nov. 28 this year, while last year it was Nov. 23.
But without a blockbuster product like last year's Windows 95 software, consumer electronics are lagging.

"Industry sales trends remained weak and promotional activity intensified," said Richard Sharp, Chairman of Circuit City Stores Inc., the largest retailer of brand-name consumer electronics and a leading retailer of personal computers.
"Promotions in consumer electronics were atrocious, I mean really terrible (for retailers' profits)," Yaari said, citing computer monitor and television giveaways with other purchases.

November same-store sales at both Best Buy Co. and Circuit City were down a sharp 8 percent, while Tandy Corp.'s sales fell 2 percent. During the same period last year, Best Buy's comparable store sales rose 15 percent.
"I think it's going to end up being one of the best years in the last four for apparel, and for consumer electronics one of the worst," said Dean Ramos, a retail analyst for Dain Bosworth Inc.
The Dain Bosworth November same-store sales index rose 3.7 percent, compared with 3.1 percent last year.

J.C. Penney Co. Inc. said its same-store sales gained 2.5 percent last month. Dayton Hudson Corp. said its November same-store sales rose 1.3 percent, including a 7 percent rise in its Target discount stores. Its department stores had a 10.5 percent slide and its Mervyn's unit saw a 9 percent drop.

One notable exception was Gymboree Corp., which reported that November same-store sales slumped 15 percent. Its stock skidded $4.875, or nearly 18 percent, to $22.875 in early afternoon trading on Nasdaq.

For retailers overall, business is going well, said Richard Jaffe of Schroder Wertheim. "It look's like it'll be a strong holiday. Day-to-day business is good, with much less promotional and more regular pricing."
